title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text: Welcome to PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis! I am very excited to join you as your instructor this quarter. Our journey together this quarter will take us through the basics of Data Science, and aims to prepare you for your future endeavors in the field (whether they be in classes, or in industry). Here’s to a great quarter!     – Ethan

title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text:
Prerequisites:

PSTAT 120A (Probability at a calculus-based level)
MATH 4A (a first pass at Linear Algebra)
Prior experience with a programming language (e.g. Python through CMPSC 9 or CMPSC 16).

Note on Programming: the primary programming language of this course will be R, though you are not expected to necessarily have prior experience coding with R (so long as you have experience coding in another language, e.g. R, Julia, etc.)

title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text:
Learning Outcomes
By the end of this course, you should be able to:

critically assess data quality and sampling design
retrieve, inspect, and clean raw data
understand the basics of exploratory, descriptive, visual, and inferential techniques
interpret and communicate results in context

title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text:
Course Description
As stated in the catalog description:

Overview of data science key concepts and the use of tools for data retrieval, analysis, visualization, and reproducible research. Topics include an introduction to inference and prediction, principles of measurement, missing data, and notions of causality, statistical “traps”, and concepts in data ethics and privacy. Case studies will illustrate the importance of domain knowledge. Credit units: 4.

Indeed, this course is designed to be a hands-on introduction to Data Science for intermediate-level students with some exposure to probability and basic computation skills, but with few or no upper-division courses in statistics.

title: Lecture 02
text:
What’s data science?


RendererRegistry.enable('html')


Data science is a term of art encompassing a wide range of activities that involve uncovering insights from quantitative information.
. . .
People that refer to themselves as data scientists typically combine specific interests (“domain knowledge”, e.g., biology) with computation, mathematics, and statistics and probability to contribute to knowledge in their communities.

Intersectional in nature
No singular disciplinary background among practitioners

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data science lifecycle

Data science lifecycle: an end-to-end process resulting in a data analysis product


Question formulation
Data collection and cleaning
Exploration
Analysis

. . .
These form a cycle in the sense that the steps are iterated for question refinement and futher discovery.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data science lifecylce

. . .
The point isn’t really the exact steps, but rather the notion of an iterative process.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Starting with a question
The scaling of brains with bodies is thought to contain clues about evolutionary patterns pertaining to intelligence.
. . .
There are lots of datasets out there with brain and body weight measurements, so let’s consider the question:

What is the relationship between an animal’s brain and body weight?

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data acquisition
From Allison et al. 1976, average body and brain weights for 62 mammals.

# import brain and body weights
bb_weights = pd.read_csv('../data/allison1976.csv').iloc[:, 0:3]
bb_weights.head(3)

brain_wt

brain weight in grams

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data assessment
How well-matched is the data to our question?

Mammals only (no birds, fish, reptiles, etc.)
Species are those for which convenient specimens were available
Averages across specimens are reported (‘aggregated’ data)

. . .
What do you think? Take a moment to discuss with your neighbor.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data assessment
Based on the great points you just made, we really only stand to learn something about this particular sample of animals.
. . .
In other words, no inference is possible.
. . .

Do you think the data are still useful?

title: Lecture 02
text:
Inpection
This dataset is already impeccably neat: each row is an observation for some species of mammal, and the columns are the two variables (average weight).
So no tidying needed – we’ll just check the dimensions and see if any values are missing.

# dimensions?
bb_weights.shape

(62, 3)



# missing values?
bb_weights.isna().sum(axis = 0)

species     0
body_wt     0
brain_wt    0
dtype: int64

title: Lecture 02
text:
Exploration
Visualization is usually a good starting point for exploring data.

# plot
alt.Chart(
  bb_weights
).mark_circle(
  color = "#fa8b2f",
  size = 100,
  opacity = 1
).encode(
  x = alt.X('body_wt', axis = alt.Axis(
    labelColor = 'white',
    titleColor = 'white')),
  y = alt.Y('brain_wt', axis = alt.Axis(
    labelColor = 'white',
    titleColor = 'white'))
).configure(
  background='#002b36',
).configure_axis(
  labelFontSize=20,
  titleFontSize=30
)







Notice the apparent density of points near \((0, 0)\) – that suggests we shouldn’t look for a relationship on the scale of kg/g.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Exploration
A simple transformation of the axes reveals a clearer pattern.

# plot
alt.Chart(
  bb_weights
).mark_circle(
  color = "#fa8b2f",
  size = 100,
  opacity = 1
).encode(
    x = alt.X('body_wt', 
    scale = alt.Scale(type = 'log'), 
    title = 'body weight (kg)'),
    y = alt.Y('brain_wt', 
    scale = alt.Scale(type = 'log'), 
    title = 'brain weight (g)')
).configure(
  background='#002b36',
).configure_axis(
  labelFontSize=20,
  titleFontSize=30,
  labelColor = 'white',
  titleColor = 'white'
)

title: Lecture 02
text:
Analysis
The plot shows us that there’s a roughly linear relationship on the log scale:
\[\log(\text{brain}) = \alpha \log(\text{body}) + c\]
. . .
So what does that mean in terms of brain and body weights? A little algebra and we have a “power law”:
\[(\text{brain}) \propto (\text{body})^\alpha\]
. . .
Check your understanding: what’s the proportionality constant?

title: Lecture 02
text:
Interpretation
So it appears that the brain-body scaling is well-described by a power law:

among selected specimens of these 62 species of mammal, species average brain weight is approximately proportional to a power of species average body weight

. . .
Notice that I did not say:

animals’ brains are proportional to a power of their bodies
among these 62 mammals, average brain weight is approximately proportional to a power of average body weight

title: Lecture 02
text:
Question refinement
We can now ask further, more specific questions:

Do other types of animals exhibit the same power law relationship?

. . .
To investigate, we need richer data.

title: Lecture 02
text:
(More) data acquisition
A number of authors have compiled and published ‘meta-analysis’ datasets by combining the results of multiple studies.
Below we’ll import a few of these for three different animal classes.

# import metaanalysis datasets
reptiles = pd.read_csv('../data/reptile_meta.csv')
birds = pd.read_csv('../data/bird_meta.csv', encoding = 'latin1')
mammals = pd.read_csv('../data/mammal_meta.csv', encoding = 'latin1')

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data assessment
Where does this data come from? It’s kind of a convenience sample of scientific data:

Multiple studies \(\rightarrow\) possibly different sampling and measurement protocols
Criteria for inclusion unknown \(\rightarrow\) probably neither comprehensive nor representative of all such measurements taken

. . .
So these data, while richer, are still relatively narrow in terms of generalizability.

# variables of interest
rept_vars = reptiles.columns[[0, 1, 2, 3, 7, 9, 11]].tolist()
bird_vars = birds.columns[[0, 1, 2, 3, 6, 11, 10]].tolist()
mammal_vars = mammals.columns[[0, 1, 2, 3, 6, 14, 11]].tolist()

# rename columns to consistent names
rept = reptiles.loc[:, rept_vars].rename(columns = {'Body weight (g)': 'body',
                                             'Brain weight (g)': 'brain'})

bird = birds.loc[:, bird_vars].rename(columns = {'Body mass (g)': 'body',
                                           'Brain mass (g)': 'brain'})

mamm = mammals.loc[:, mammal_vars].rename(columns = {'Body mass (g)': 'body',
                                           'Brain mass (g)': 'brain'})

# add animal indicator
mamm['class'] = 'Mammal'
bird['class'] = 'Bird'
rept['class'] = 'Reptile'

# concatenate
frames = [rept, mamm, bird]
data = pd.concat(frames)

title: Lecture 02
section: A comment on scope of inference
text:
A comment on scope of inference
These data don’t support general inferences (e.g., to all animals, all mammals, etc.) because they weren’t collected for the purpose to which we’re putting them.
. . .
Usually, if data are not collected for the explicit purpose of the question you’re trying to answer, they won’t constitute a representative sample.

title: Lecture 02
Lecture 02
text:
Inspection
This dataset is already impeccably neat: each row is an observation for some species of mammal, and the columns are the two variables (average weight).
So no tidying needed – we’ll just check the dimensions and see if any values are missing.

# dimensions?
bb_weights.shape

(62, 3)



# missing values?
bb_weights.isna().sum(axis = 0)

species     0
body_wt     0
brain_wt    0
dtype: int64

title: Lecture 02
text:
Exploration
Focusing on the nonmissing values, we see the same power law relationship but with different proportionality constants and exponents for the three classes of animals.

scatter = alt.Chart(
  avg_weights
).mark_circle(
  size = 60,
  opacity = 0.2
).encode(
    x = 'log(body)',
    y = 'log(brain)',
    color = 'class'
)

trend = scatter.transform_regression(
  'log(body)', 
  'log(brain)', 
  groupby = ['class']
).mark_line(
  size = 4
)


alt.layer(
  scatter, trend
).configure(
  background='#002b36',
).configure_axis(
  labelFontSize=20,
  titleFontSize=30,
  labelColor = 'white',
  titleColor = 'white'
).configure_legend(
  titleColor = 'white',
  labelColor = 'white',
  titleFontSize = 25,
  labelFontSize = 20,
  symbolOpacity = 1
)

title: Lecture 02
text:
Analysis
So we might hypothesize that:
\[
\begin{align*}
(\text{brain}) & = \beta_1(\text{body})^{\alpha_1} & \text{(mammal)} \\
(\text{brain}) & = \beta_2(\text{body})^{\alpha_2} & \text{(reptile)} \\
(\text{brain}) & = \beta_3(\text{body})^{\alpha_3} & \text{(bird)} \\
\beta_i \neq \beta_j, & \quad  \alpha_i \neq \alpha_j  & \text{for } i \neq j
\end{align*}
\]

title: Lecture 02
text:
Interpretation
It seems that the average brain and body weights of the birds, mammals, and reptiles measured in these studies exhibit distinct power law relationships.
. . .
What would you investigate next?

Correlates of body weight?
Adjust for lifespan, habitat, predation, etc.?
Estimate the \(\alpha_i\)’s and \(\beta_i\)’s?
Predict brain weights for unobserved species?
Something else?

title: Lecture 02
text:
A comment
Notice that I did not mention the word ‘model’ anywhere!
. . .
This was intentional – it is a common misconception that analyzing data always involves fitting models.

Models are not not always necessary or appropriate
You can learn a lot from exploratory techniques
Models approximate specific kinds of relationships in data
Exploratory analysis can reveal unexpected structure

title: Lecture 02
section: But if we did want to fit a model…
text:
But if we did want to fit a model…
\((\text{brain}) = \beta_j(\text{body})^{\alpha_j} \quad \text{animal class } j = 1, 2, 3\)

import matplotlib as mpl
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import statsmodels.api as sm
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf

data = avg_weights.loc[:, ['class', 'brain', 'body']].rename(columns={'class':'animal_type'})

body_rep = pd.concat([avg_weights.body, avg_weights.body, avg_weights.body], axis = 1)

x1 = pd.get_dummies(avg_weights.iloc[:, 0])
x2 = x1 * np.log(body_rep).values
x2 = x2.rename(columns={'Bird': 'log.body.bird', 'Mammal': 'log.body.mammal', 'Reptile': 'log.body.reptile'})

x = pd.concat([x1, x2], axis = 1)
y = np.log(avg_weights.brain)

fit = sm.OLS(y, x.astype(float)).fit()


print(np.asarray(x))

[[1.         0.         0.         5.81413053 0.         0.        ]
 [1.         0.         0.         6.29618809 0.         0.        ]
 [1.         0.         0.         8.56978564 0.         0.        ]
 ...
 [0.         0.         1.         0.         0.         8.5418858 ]
 [0.         0.         1.         0.         0.         7.52185925]
 [0.         0.         1.         0.         0.         7.25700271]]

title: Lecture 02
text:
Model limitations
Back to the issue of representativeness:

shouldn’t use this model for inferences
might not be reliable for prediction either
but does capture/convey some suggestive comparisons

. . .
So, just be careful with interpretation of results:

“For this particular collection of specimens, we estimated…”

title: Lecture 02
text:
Zooming out
This example illustrates the aspects of the lifecylce we’ll cover in this class:

data retrieval and import
tidying and transformation
visualization
exploratory analysis
modeling

. . .
We’ll address these topics in sequence.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Next week

Tabular data structure
Data semantics
Tidy data
Transformations of tabular data
Aggregation and grouping

This dataset has quite a lot of missing brain weight measurements: many of the studies combined to form these datasets did not include that particular measurement.

avg_weights['log(body)'] = np.log(avg_weights['body'])
avg_weights['log(brain)'] = np.log(avg_weights['brain'])

title: Lecture 02
section: But if we did want to fit a model…
text:
But if we did want to fit a model…

FigureEstimates



x = np.linspace(0, 100000, 100)  
y1 = np.exp(fit.params[0])*(x**fit.params[3])
y2 = np.exp(fit.params[1])*(x**fit.params[4])
y3 = np.exp(fit.params[2])*(x**fit.params[5])

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6, 3.5), layout='constrained')
ax.plot(x/1000, y1, label='birds')  # Plot some data on the axes.
ax.plot(x/1000, y2, label='mammals')  # Plot more data on the axes...
ax.plot(x/1000, y3, label='reptiles')  # ... and some more.
ax.set_xlabel('body weight (kg)',
  fontsize = 18,
  color = 'white')  # Add an x-label to the axes.
ax.set_ylabel('median brain weight (g)',
  fontsize = 18,
  color = 'white')  # Add a y-label to the axes.
ax.legend()  # Add a legend.

ax.set_facecolor('#002b36')
fig.set_facecolor('#002b36')
ax.tick_params(colors='white')

Notice that I did not mention the word ‘model’ anywhere!

This was intentional – it is a common misconception that analyzing data always involves fitting models.

Models are not not always necessary or appropriate
You can learn a lot from exploratory techniques
Models approximate specific kinds of relationships in data
Exploratory analysis can reveal unexpected structure

title: Lecture 01
section: But if we did want to fit a model…

title: Lecture 01
section: But if we did want to fit a model…

title: Lecture 01
text:
Model limitations
Back to the issue of representativeness:

shouldn’t use this model for inferences
might not be reliable for prediction either
but does capture/convey some suggestive comparisons


So, just be careful with interpretation of results:

“For this particular collection of specimens, we estimated…”

title: Lecture 01
text:
Zooming out
This example illustrates the aspects of the lifecylce we’ll cover in this class:

data retrieval and import
tidying and transformation
visualization
exploratory analysis
modeling


We’ll address these topics in sequence.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Next week

Tabular data structure
Data semantics
Tidy data
Transformations of tabular data
Aggregation and grouping

Policies

Please note: email should not be used as a primary means of communication.

We (the course staff) would much rather you please bring questions to Office Hours, or the Discussion Board.
Please note that emails will, in general, be ignored unless you have spoken with a course staff member and received instructions to send an email.
This is not just for the sake of our inboxes, but your peace of mind as well!

title: Lecture 01
text: What Is Data?

title: Lecture 01
text:
What Is Data?

According to Merriam-Webster (source), there are three definitions for data:


factual information (such as measurements or statistics) used as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or calculation
information in digital form that can be transmitted or processed
information output by a sensing device or organ that includes both useful and irrelevant or redundant information and must be processed to be meaningful

title: Lecture 01
text:
What Is Data?

I like the first definition!

“[…] used as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or calculation.”
Raw data is very often uninterpretable, or even useless.
It’s the job of a Data Scientist to interpret the data, and use it to assess beliefs.

Data Literacy: “the ability to explore, understand, and communicate with data in a meaningful way.” (source)

Part of what we’ll learn this quarter!

title: Lecture 01
text:
What is Data?

We will revisit the question of what data is (and how it can be represented) next week.
Example for now: palmerpenguins
Collected by Dr. Kristen Gorman at the Palmer Station in Antarctica

344 penguins observed, and 8 characteristics observed (e.g. species, bill length (in mm), body mass (in g), etc.)

title: Lecture 01
text:
palmerpenguins

In the data matrix representation, rows are called observational units and columns are called variables.

For instance: in the palmerpenguins dataset, there are 344 observational units (each corresponding to a particular penguin) and 8 variables (each corresponding to one of the characteristics observed on each penguin).

What does each variable mean?

For example, what is island?

A data dictionary is a verbal description of precisely what each variable represents.

title: Lecture 01
text:
palmerpenguins Data Dictionary








Variable
Description




species
The species of penguin (either Adelie, Chinstrap, or Gentoo)


island
The island on which the penguin was found (either Biscoe, Dream, or Torgersen)


bill_length_mm
The length (millimeters) of the penguin’s bill


bill_depth_mm
The depth (in millimeters) of the penguin’s bill


flipper_length_mm
The length (in millimeters) of the penguin’s flipper


body_mass_g
The mass (in grams) of the penguin


sex
The sex of the penguin (either Male or Female)


year
The year in which the penguin was observed

title: Lecture 01
text:
Inferences

Given the results of the palmerpenguins dataset …

… what can we say about the proportion of penguins in Antarctica that are Biscoe?
… what can we say about the true average flipper length of penguins?
… can we conclude that the average penguin weighs 4200 grams?

These are some examples of questions we ask in Statistical Inference.

title: PSTAT 100: Spring 2024
text:
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

air = pd.read_csv('air-quality.csv').fillna(
    axis = 0, 
    method = 'ffill'
).drop(
    columns = ['Number of Trends Sites', 'CBSA']
).melt(
    id_vars = ['Core Based Statistical Area', 'Pollutant', 'Trend Statistic'],
    var_name = 'Year',
    value_name = 'Measurement'
).pivot_table(
    index = ['Core Based Statistical Area', 'Year'],
    columns = ['Pollutant', 'Trend Statistic'],
    values = 'Measurement'
).reset_index()

air['State'] = air['Core Based Statistical Area'].str.split(pat = ',', expand = True).loc[:, 1]
air['City'] = air['Core Based Statistical Area'].str.split(pat = ',', expand = True).loc[:, 0]

air.columns = air.columns.get_level_values(level = 0)

air_tidy = air.rename_axis(columns = '').drop(columns = 'Core Based Statistical Area')

air_tidy.to_csv('air.csv', index = False)

title: Lecture 01
Lecture 01
text:
Inference

Given the results of the palmerpenguins dataset …

… what can we say about the proportion of penguins in Antarctica that are Biscoe?
… what can we say about the true average flipper length of penguins?
… can we conclude that the average penguin weighs 4200 grams?

These are some examples of questions we ask in Statistical Inference.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Sampling

To answer some of these sorts of questions, we’ll need to question and examine the way in which the palmerpenguins data was collected.

title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text:
Assessments

Labs will be assigned weekly in most weeks. These are structured coding assignments with small exercises throughout that introduce the programming skills needed to complete homework assignments.
Homeworks will be assigned biweekly. These are fairly involved assignments which apply concepts and techniques from the lectures and programming skills from the labs to real data sets in order to reproduce an analysis and answer substantive questions. Collaboration is encouraged, but students must write up and submit their own work individually.
Mini projects will be assigned biweekly in alternation with homeworks. These assignments prompt students to use skills from the course in an unstructured setting to answer high-level questions pertaining to one or more datasets. Mini projects should be completed collaboratively.
A course project will be assigned requiring students to carry out an open-ended data analysis. This will be completed in teams.
2 In-Class Assessments will be administered (see below for dates). I hesitate to call these “exams” because they are not intended to be as high-stakes as exams, however they are designed to test your retention of course material.







Assessment Dates




In-Class Assessment 1: TBD in BUCHN 1940 (our Lecture classroom)
In-Class Assessment 2: TBD in BUCHN 1940 (our Lecture classroom)




Final Course Grades
Your final course grade will be computed according to the following weights:



Assessment
Weight




Labs
20%


HW
30%


Projects
30%


In-Class Assessments
20%



Your final letter grade will be issued according to the following scheme (cutoffs between plusses and minuses will be calculated at the end of the quarter):

A- – A+: 90 – 100%
B– – B+: 80 – 89.99%
C– – C+: 70 – 79.99%
D– – D+ : 60 – 69.99%
F: 0 – 59.99%

I have elected to adopt an uncurved grading scheme to eliminate any sense of “competition” among students; I highly encourage you all to collaborate with and uplift each other. Having said that, I will certainly consider adjusting the cutoffs (naturally, in everyone’s favor) at the end of the quarter if necessary.(Basically, I may curve up but I will not curve down.)

title: Lecture 01
text: Lifecycle

title: Lecture 02
text:
What Is Data Science?

Still some debate; there isn’t one single agreed-upon definition.
Most people agree Data Science is Cross-Disciplinary; i.e. it lies at the intersection of many fields.
Often, data scientists are concerned with contributing knowledge by way of combining three things: statistical theory and methodology, with computer science technology, and domain-specific knowledge.

For example, to make claims about air quality, a data scientist might utilize appropriate statistical methodology in conjunction with sophisticated computer science algorithms, along with specific knowledge from ecology, atmospheric science, anthropology, and potentially many other fields.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Collaborative!

As such, data science is inherently collaborative!

As a Data Scientist, you will very often be working with experts from a variety of different fields (sometimes all at once).
This is true both from an academic standpoint (i.e. if you plan to pursue a data science career in academia) and from an industry standpoint.

This is part of the reason the projects in PSTAT 100 are completed in groups: to give you practice with project management in a group setting.

title: Lecture 02
text: Data Science Lifecycle

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data Science Lifecycle






Two possible entry points: with a question or with a data set



Are you starting your analyses with a specific question in mind? (“How has air quality changed over time?” “What factors affect feline contraction of FIV?” etc.)




Or, are you starting with a specific dataset you want to explore, from which you will (ultimately) formulate a question of interest?

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data Science Lifecycle






The exact steps are not that important (and also not fully agreed-upon).



The main idea is of an iterative process.




Maybe your data will change the question you ask. Maybe, after a first pass, you will realize you need additional data.




UCSB: Department of Statistics and Applied Probability

The main idea is of an iterative process.

title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text: Welcome to PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis! I am very excited to join you as your instructor this quarter. Our journey together will take us through the basics of Data Science, and aims to prepare you for your future endeavors in the field, whether they be in classes, industry, or academia. Here’s to a great quarter!     – Ethan

title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text:
Course Description
As stated in the catalog description:

Overview of data science key concepts and the use of tools for data retrieval, analysis, visualization, and reproducible research. Topics include an introduction to inference and prediction, principles of measurement, missing data, and notions of causality, statistical “traps”, and concepts in data ethics and privacy. Case studies will illustrate the importance of domain knowledge. Credit units: 4.

Indeed, this course is designed to be a hands-on introduction to Data Science for intermediate-level students with some exposure to probability and basic computation skills, but with few or no upper-division courses in statistics.

title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text:
Prerequisites:

PSTAT 120A (Probability at a calculus-based level)
MATH 4A (a first pass at Linear Algebra)
Prior experience with a programming language (e.g. Python through CMPSC 9 or CMPSC 16).

Note on Programming: the primary programming language of this course will be R, though you are not expected to necessarily have prior experience coding with R (so long as you have experience coding in another language, e.g. Python, Julia, etc.)

title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text:
Learning Outcomes
By the end of this course, you should be able to:

critically assess data quality and sampling design
retrieve, inspect, and clean raw data
understand the basics of exploratory, descriptive, visual, and inferential techniques
interpret and communicate results in context

title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text:
Assessments

Labs: short, structured coding assignments designed to introduce programming concepts and skills. Labs will be assigned weekly, and are designed to be mostly completed during Section on Monday but won’t be due until 11:59pm on Wednesdays.
Homeworks: slightly larger in scope than labs; will contain both programming and theoretical/conceptual concepts. We will have a total of 3 homework assignments released throughout the quarter; typically you will have 1-2 weeks to work on the homeworks and you are encouraged to start as early as possible!
Mini Projects: more open-ended than homeworks and labs, and are designed to more closely simulate real-world data science projects and endeavors. We will have a total of 3 mini projects (released in non-exam weeks where there are no homeworks due) throughout the quarter, and you are encouraged to work collaboratively.
Final Project: a final, comprehensive project that will be due during finals week. You will be required to work in teams on the Final Project.







Final Project



The final project will be due by 11:59pm on Tuesday, June 11.



2 In-Class Assessments (ICAs) will be administered (see below for dates). I hesitate to call these “exams” because they are not intended to be as high-stakes as exams, however they are designed to test your retention of course material. More information will be released as we approach the date of the first ICA.







Assessment Dates




In-Class Assessment 1: Thursday, April 25, 2024 in BUCHN 1940 (our Lecture classroom) starting at 9:30 (our regular class time)
In-Class Assessment 2: Thursday, May 23, 2024 in BUCHN 1940 (our Lecture classroom) starting at 9:30 (our regular class time)

There will be no ICAs offered at alternate times, for any reasons. So, please plan accordingly!

Collaboration and Academic Integrity
Data Science (as we will see) is an inherently collaborative field. As such, you are not only allowed but also encouraged to collaborate on assignments (be they lab, homework, or project). However, there are limitations to collaboration:

collaboration on the ICAs is strictly prohibited
do not copy other people’s work and try to pass it off as your own
if/when you work in groups, include the names of all group members on the assignment

Anyone found guilty of academic misconduct will be reported to the Academic Senate, and will receive at minimum a failing grade on the assignment in question; further actions may also include failing the course, and marks being made on permanent records. Depending on the severity of the infraction, expulsion is also a possibility.
Basically, don’t cheat- please! If you’re ever struggling with course material, please come talk to me or the TA’s. We are truly here for you, and want only the best for you.


Section Switching
Lab Sections take place in special “Collaborate Classrooms” which are equipped with laptops. There are only a fixed number of seats and laptops in these classrooms, meaning we cannot under any circumstance over-enroll sections. Therefore, if you want to switch section unofficially (we do not have the ability to switch your official enrollment through GOLD), please follow the steps at this link. Any requests to switch sections that do not adhere to the guidelines posted at that link will be ignored.

title: Lecture 00
text: What Is Data?

title: Lecture 00
text:
What Is Data?

According to Merriam-Webster (source), there are three definitions for data:


factual information (such as measurements or statistics) used as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or calculation
information in digital form that can be transmitted or processed
information output by a sensing device or organ that includes both useful and irrelevant or redundant information and must be processed to be meaningful

title: Lecture 00
text:
What Is Data?

I like the first definition!

“[…] used as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or calculation.”
Raw data is very often uninterpretable, or even useless.
It’s the job of a Data Scientist to interpret the data, and use it to assess beliefs.

Data Literacy: “the ability to explore, understand, and communicate with data in a meaningful way.” (source)

Part of what we’ll learn this quarter!

title: Lecture 00
text:
What is Data?

We will revisit the question of what data is (and how it can be represented) next week.
Example for now: palmerpenguins
Collected by Dr. Kristen Gorman at the Palmer Station in Antarctica

344 penguins observed, and 8 characteristics observed (e.g. species, bill length (in mm), body mass (in g), etc.)

title: Lecture 00
text:
palmerpenguins

In the data matrix representation, rows are called observational units and columns are called variables.

For instance: in the palmerpenguins dataset, there are 344 observational units (each corresponding to a particular penguin) and 8 variables (each corresponding to one of the characteristics observed on each penguin).

What does each variable mean?

For example, what is island?

A data dictionary is a verbal description of precisely what each variable represents.

title: Lecture 00
text:
palmerpenguins Data Dictionary








Variable
Description




species
The species of penguin (either Adelie, Chinstrap, or Gentoo)


island
The island on which the penguin was found (either Biscoe, Dream, or Torgersen)


bill_length_mm
The length (millimeters) of the penguin’s bill


bill_depth_mm
The depth (in millimeters) of the penguin’s bill


flipper_length_mm
The length (in millimeters) of the penguin’s flipper


body_mass_g
The mass (in grams) of the penguin


sex
The sex of the penguin (either Male or Female)


year
The year in which the penguin was observed

text:

title: Lecture 00
text:
Inference

Given the results of the palmerpenguins dataset …

… what can we say about the proportion of penguins in Antarctica that are Biscoe?
… what can we say about the true average flipper length of penguins?
… can we conclude that the average penguin weighs 4200 grams?

These are some examples of questions we ask in Statistical Inference.

title: Lecture 00
text:
Sampling

To answer some of these sorts of questions, we’ll need to question and examine the way in which the palmerpenguins data was collected.

Primary portal where assignments will be submitted and graded. (We’ll also handle all regrade requests through Gradescope.)

title: Lecture 00
text:
Course Assessments

Labs: 20% of final grade

Designed to help you practice your coding skills.
Plan to complete the majority of lab assessments during Section.

Homework: 20% of final grade

Larger in scope than labs; may test not only on programming but also conceptual topics.
Assigned more-or-less biweekly.

title: Lecture 00
text:
Course Assessments

Course Projects: 30% of final grade

Assigned biweekly, in non-homework weeks
Very open-ended; designed to give you practice answering high-level questions, and give you a sense of what a “real-world” data science project might look like.

In-Class Assessments: 30% of final grade (15% each)

Kind of like an exam; will test conceptual and programming topics from lectures, homework, and projects.

Please read the syllabus!

title: Lecture 00
text:
Assorted Policies

Late work: you are allowed two late submissions (across homework, labs, and projects)

Work must be submitted within 48 hours of original deadline; no work will be accepted beyond 48 hours post-original-deadline.
No late policies for In-Class Assessments

Email Please refrain from using email to contact course staff

See course website for appropriate communications channels. Kindly note that unauthorized emails to course staff will not receive replies.

title: Lecture 00
text:
Syllabus

Again: Please read the syllabus!




UCSB: Department of Statistics and Applied Probability

title: Lecture 00
text:
Programming

Technically, a prerequisite for this course is CS 9 or CS 16.
Really, prior exposure to any programming language will do.
We will be using R this quarter (we’ll discuss this further in Lab00).
Server: https://pstat100.lsit.ucsb.edu

Although the server makes it so that you technically don’t need to download R and RStudio, I highly recommend you download the appropriate software so you can save backups of your work on your local machine.

title: Lecture 00
text:
Other Prerequisites

Another prerequisite for this course is PSTAT 120A.

We’ll be referncing probability distributions quite often this quarter, as well as concepts like expected value, variance, etc.
It also helps to have been exposed to the probabilistic way of thinking.

Math 4A

We’ll be using: matrix manipulations, eigenvalues/eigenvectors, projections, and a few other concepts.

title: Lecture 00
text:
PSTAT 100

So, what will we be doing this quarter?


Developing our R skills
Developing our data literacy: (more on this in a bit)
Applying our skills to multiple real-world datasets and projects


At the end of this course, I (loosely speaking) hope to have set you up for success in both your future data science courses and your future careers in data science

A full set of learning objectives can be found on the course website.

title: Lecture 01
text: What Is Data?

title: Lecture 01
text:
What Is Data?

According to Merriam-Webster (source), there are three definitions for data:


factual information (such as measurements or statistics) used as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or calculation
information in digital form that can be transmitted or processed
information output by a sensing device or organ that includes both useful and irrelevant or redundant information and must be processed to be meaningful

title: Lecture 01
text:
What Is Data?

I like the first definition!

“[…] used as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or calculation.”
Raw data is very often uninterpretable, or even useless.
It’s the job of a Data Scientist to interpret the data, and use it to assess beliefs.

Data Literacy: “the ability to explore, understand, and communicate with data in a meaningful way.” (source)

Part of what we’ll learn this quarter!

title: Lecture 01
text:
What is Data?

We will revisit the question of what data is (and how it can be represented) next week.
Example for now: palmerpenguins
Collected by Dr. Kristen Gorman at the Palmer Station in Antarctica

344 penguins observed, and 8 characteristics observed (e.g. species, bill length (in mm), body mass (in g), etc.)

title: Lecture 01
text:
palmerpenguins

In the data matrix representation, rows are called observational units and columns are called variables.

For instance: in the palmerpenguins dataset, there are 344 observational units (each corresponding to a particular penguin) and 8 variables (each corresponding to one of the characteristics observed on each penguin).

We will talk more about different representations for data next week.
I’d like to stress that the data itself are the entries inside the table on the previous slide.

At its core, data is just a collection of values.

title: Lecture 01
text:
palmerpenguins

What does each variable mean?

For example, what is island?

A data dictionary is a verbal description of precisely what each variable represents.

Most datasets will come equipped with a data dictionary (though it may not be as neatly formatted as a table or list; you may need to read through documentation to determine what the variables in a given dataset represent)

title: Lecture 01
text:
palmerpenguins Data Dictionary








Variable
Description




species
The species of penguin (either Adelie, Chinstrap, or Gentoo)


island
The island on which the penguin was found (either Biscoe, Dream, or Torgersen)


bill_length_mm
The length (millimeters) of the penguin’s bill


bill_depth_mm
The depth (in millimeters) of the penguin’s bill


flipper_length_mm
The length (in millimeters) of the penguin’s flipper


body_mass_g
The mass (in grams) of the penguin


sex
The sex of the penguin (either Male or Female)


year
The year in which the penguin was observed

title: Lecture 01
text:
Inference

Given the results of the palmerpenguins dataset …

… what can we say about the proportion of penguins in Antarctica that are Biscoe?
… what can we say about the true average flipper length of penguins?
… can we conclude that the average penguin weighs 4200 grams?

These are some examples of questions we ask in Statistical Inference.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Sampling

To answer some of these sorts of questions, we’ll need to question and examine the way in which the palmerpenguins data was collected.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Graphical Summaries

Without Coloring by SpeciesColoring by Species

title: Lecture 01
text:
Descriptive Statistics

We’ll talk more about visualizations a few weeks from now.
Visualizations (i.e. graphs) are a subset of what is known as Descriptive Statistics, which is the branch of statistics primarily concerned with describing data.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Other Questions

We could start asking questions about our dataset as well.
For example, we could try and use the palmerpenguins dataset to test claims about penguins as a whole.

E.g. given the data we saw, is it plausible to claim that the average penguin weighs 4200 grams?

This leads us to the branch of statistics known as Inferential Statistics, which is primarily concerned with using our data to make inferences about some population.

We’ll talk about inferential statistics on several occasions throughout this course.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Other Questions

At some point, we will also need to critically examine how our data was collected.

This will lead us into a discussion on sampling.

What do we do if some of our data is missing?

This will lead us into a discussion on data imputation

title: Lecture 01
text: What Is Data?

title: Lecture 01
text:
What Is Data?

According to Merriam-Webster (source), there are three definitions for data:


factual information (such as measurements or statistics) used as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or calculation
information in digital form that can be transmitted or processed
information output by a sensing device or organ that includes both useful and irrelevant or redundant information and must be processed to be meaningful

title: Lecture 01
text:
What Is Data?

I like the first definition!

“[…] used as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or calculation.”
Raw data is very often uninterpretable, or even useless.
It’s the job of a Data Scientist to interpret the data, and use it to assess beliefs.

Data Literacy: “the ability to explore, understand, and communicate with data in a meaningful way.” (source)

Part of what we’ll learn this quarter!

title: Lecture 01
text:
What is Data?

We will revisit the question of what data is (and how it can be represented) next week.
Example for now: palmerpenguins
Collected by Dr. Kristen Gorman at the Palmer Station in Antarctica

344 penguins observed, and 8 characteristics observed (e.g. species, bill length (in mm), body mass (in g), etc.)

title: Lecture 01
text:
Acknowledgments

Palmer Penguins: https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/
R Packages used: palmerpenguins, tidyverse, pander, knitr.
Slides created in Quarto, using RevealJS.




UCSB: Department of Statistics and Applied Probability

title: Lecture 01
text:
Data

We will spend a lot of time this quarter discussing different ways to represent data (both tabularly and visually).
There are two things to think of when it comes to a dataset: semantics and structure.

Semantics: what do the values in a dataset actually represent?
Structure: how can we display the values in a dataset?

Every value in a dataset (sometimes called a datum) is an observation of a variable taken on an observational unit.
Let’s parse through these concepts.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Observational Units

An observational unit is the entity that is being measured.

For example, in the palmerpenguins dataset, the observational units are the 344 different penguins that the researchers encountered.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Observations, Variables, and Observational Units

An observational unit is the entity that is being measured.

For example, in the palmerpenguins dataset, the observational units are the 344 different penguins that the researchers encountered.

A variable can be thought of as some sort of attribute or quantity being measured.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Observational Units and Variables

An observational unit is the entity that is being measured.

For example, in the palmerpenguins dataset, the observational units are the 344 different penguins that the researchers encountered.

A variable can be thought of as some sort of attribute or quantity being measured.

For example, the palmerpenguins dataset has 8 variables.
A dictionary is an explicit specification of what each variable in a dataset represents.

title: Lecture 01
text:
palmerpenguins Data Dictionary








Variable
Description




species
The species of penguin (either Adelie, Chinstrap, or Gentoo)


island
The island on which the penguin was found (either Biscoe, Dream, or Torgersen)


bill_length_mm
The length (millimeters) of the penguin’s bill


bill_depth_mm
The depth (in millimeters) of the penguin’s bill


flipper_length_mm
The length (in millimeters) of the penguin’s flipper


body_mass_g
The mass (in grams) of the penguin


sex
The sex of the penguin (either Male or Female)


year
The year in which the penguin was observed

text: source: https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/

title: Lecture 01
text:
Leadup

Let’s take a look at the observations in the palmerpenguins dataset again, this time paying attention to which variable they were taken on.
We can see that there are, at the broadest level, two types of values: words (e.g. Adelie, male, Torgersen, etc.) and numbers (e.g. 39.1, 2007, etc.)
This leads us to the notion of variable classification.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Numerical vs. Categorical

At the highest level of classification, variables can be labeled as either numerical or categorical (sometimes called quantitative and qualitative, respectively).
Numerical variables are those whose observations take the form of numbers.

Examples include height, weight, population size, GDP, etc.

Categorical variables are those whose observations take the form of categories.

Examples include: species, opinions, letter grades, etc.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Numerical vs. Categorical






Caution


It is a faux-pas to conclude that a variable is numerical solely based on the fact that its observations are numbers.




For instance, we can encode observations on months (e.g. months in which we have rain in Satna Barbara) using 01 for January, 02 for February, etc.
This does not make month a numerical variable; 1 + 2 is 3, but January + February is not March!

title: Lecture 01
text:
Numerical vs. Categorical

So, we should really look at whether differences (or, analogously, sums) of observations within the variable have interpretive meaning or not.

If they have interpretive meaning, then the variable is numerical. Otherwise, it is categorical.









Your Turn!


Turn to your neighbor(s), and come up with a few examples of numerical variables and a few examples of categorical variables. Write these down, as we’ll revisit them later!

title: Lecture 01
text:
Ordinal vs. Nominal

Categorical variables can be further subdivided into two classes: ordinal and nominal.
Ordinal variables are those whose categories have an implicit/natural ordering.

For example, letter grades is an ordinal variable as A+ is in considered to be “better” than A, which is considered to be “better” than A-, etc.

Nominal variables are those whose categories do not have an implicit ordering.

For example, favorite color is a nominal variable as green is not inherently “better” than orange, which is not inherently “better” than blue, etc.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Discrete vs. Continuous

Analagously, numerical variables also have a second level of classification, into discrete and continuous.
To distinguish between discrete and continuous variables, we need to look at the set of possible values the variable can take.
If this set of possible values has “jumps”, then the variable is discrete. Otherwise, it is continuous.
For example, take number of accidents in a given day: the set of possible values of this variable is \(\{0, 1, 2, \cdots\} = \N \cup \{0\}\), which has “jumps”; it is impossible to observe 1.5 accidents on a given day. Hence, number of accidents in a given day is a discrete variable.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Discrete Vs. Continuous

Take a look at the following dataset (called AirPassengers), which contains monthly totals of international airline passengers between 1949 and 1960.

title: Lecture 01
text:
Discrete vs. Continuous

Strictly speaking, time is a continuous variable.
However, in the AirPassengers dataset, time only takes a finite set of values (e.g. Jan 1949, Feb 1949, etc.)








Context is Key








Depending on our goals, it may be beneficial to treat time of observation as either discrete or continuous (but observed on only a discrete set of values).

title: Lecture 01
text:
Connection to Programming

Let’s close off this lecture by connecting the concepts we discussed to programming.
As a prerequisite for this course is proficiency in at least one programming language, hopefully everyone remembers the notion of data types and data structures.
Data types refer to the way fundamental units in a programming language are encoded.
There are four main data types in R: integer, double (i.e. real numbers), character (i.e. string), and logical (i.e. boolean).

title: Lecture 01
text:
Programming

Let’s close off this lecture by connecting the concepts we discussed to programming.
As a prerequisite for this course is proficiency in at least one programming language, hopefully everyone remembers the notion of data types and data structures.
Data types refer to the way fundamental units in a programming language are encoded.
There are four main data types in R: integer, double (i.e. real numbers), character (i.e. string), and logical (i.e. boolean).

title: Lecture 01
text:
Programming


typeof(1L)

[1] "integer"





typeof(1)

[1] "double"





typeof("hello world")

[1] "character"





typeof(FALSE)

[1] "logical"

title: Lecture 01
text:
Programming

Individual units/values can be combined into larger data structures:.
In R, these include things like:

Vectors (lists of numbers)
Matrices (much like the mathematical notion of a matrix)
Arrays (much like a tensor; i.e. stacks of matrices)
Factors (good for categorical data)
Data Frames (allows for different data types)
Tibbles (very similar to data frames)

title: Lecture 01
text:
Factors

As mentioned above, factors are a great way to encode categorical data.



x_factor <- factor(c("x", "y", "z", "x", "y"))
x_factor

[1] x y z x y
Levels: x y z

class(x_factor)

[1] "factor"

levels(x_factor) # can you tell me what this does?

[1] "x" "y" "z"

title: Lecture 01
text:
Ordered Factors

If we have ordinal data, we can use an ordered factor to store our data:



law_and_order <- factor(
  c("law", "and", "order", "and", "order"),
  ordered = TRUE,
  levels = c("law", "and", "order")
)

law_and_order

[1] law   and   order and   order
Levels: law < and < order

title: Lecture 00
Lecture 02
Lecture 02
text:
What’s data science?


RendererRegistry.enable('html')


Data science is a term of art encompassing a wide range of activities that involve uncovering insights from quantitative information.
. . .
People that refer to themselves as data scientists typically combine specific interests (“domain knowledge”, e.g., biology) with computation, mathematics, and statistics and probability to contribute to knowledge in their communities.

Intersectional in nature
No singular disciplinary background among practitioners

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data science lifecycle

Data science lifecycle: an end-to-end process resulting in a data analysis product


Question formulation
Data collection and cleaning
Exploration
Analysis

. . .
These form a cycle in the sense that the steps are iterated for question refinement and futher discovery.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data science lifecylce

. . .
The point isn’t really the exact steps, but rather the notion of an iterative process.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Starting with a question
The scaling of brains with bodies is thought to contain clues about evolutionary patterns pertaining to intelligence.
. . .
There are lots of datasets out there with brain and body weight measurements, so let’s consider the question:

What is the relationship between an animal’s brain and body weight?

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data acquisition
From Allison et al. 1976, average body and brain weights for 62 mammals.

# import brain and body weights
bb_weights = pd.read_csv('../data/allison1976.csv').iloc[:, 0:3]
bb_weights.head(3)








species
body_wt
brain_wt




0
Africanelephant
6654.000
5712.0


1
Africangiantpouchedrat
1.000
6.6


2
ArcticFox
3.385
44.5







Units of measurement

body weight in kilograms
brain weight in grams

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data assessment
How well-matched is the data to our question?

Mammals only (no birds, fish, reptiles, etc.)
Species are those for which convenient specimens were available
Averages across specimens are reported (‘aggregated’ data)

. . .
What do you think? Take a moment to discuss with your neighbor.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data assessment
Based on the great points you just made, we really only stand to learn something about this particular sample of animals.
. . .
In other words, no inference is possible.
. . .

Do you think the data are still useful?

title: Lecture 02
text:
Inspection
This dataset is already impeccably neat: each row is an observation for some species of mammal, and the columns are the two variables (average weight).
So no tidying needed – we’ll just check the dimensions and see if any values are missing.

# dimensions?
bb_weights.shape

(62, 3)



# missing values?
bb_weights.isna().sum(axis = 0)

species     0
body_wt     0
brain_wt    0
dtype: int64

title: Lecture 02
text:
Exploration
Visualization is usually a good starting point for exploring data.

# plot
alt.Chart(
  bb_weights
).mark_circle(
  color = "#fa8b2f",
  size = 100,
  opacity = 1
).encode(
  x = alt.X('body_wt', axis = alt.Axis(
    labelColor = 'white',
    titleColor = 'white')),
  y = alt.Y('brain_wt', axis = alt.Axis(
    labelColor = 'white',
    titleColor = 'white'))
).configure(
  background='#002b36',
).configure_axis(
  labelFontSize=20,
  titleFontSize=30
)







Notice the apparent density of points near \((0, 0)\) – that suggests we shouldn’t look for a relationship on the scale of kg/g.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Exploration
A simple transformation of the axes reveals a clearer pattern.

# plot
alt.Chart(
  bb_weights
).mark_circle(
  color = "#fa8b2f",
  size = 100,
  opacity = 1
).encode(
    x = alt.X('body_wt', 
    scale = alt.Scale(type = 'log'), 
    title = 'body weight (kg)'),
    y = alt.Y('brain_wt', 
    scale = alt.Scale(type = 'log'), 
    title = 'brain weight (g)')
).configure(
  background='#002b36',
).configure_axis(
  labelFontSize=20,
  titleFontSize=30,
  labelColor = 'white',
  titleColor = 'white'
)

title: Lecture 02
text:
Analysis
The plot shows us that there’s a roughly linear relationship on the log scale:
\[\log(\text{brain}) = \alpha \log(\text{body}) + c\]
. . .
So what does that mean in terms of brain and body weights? A little algebra and we have a “power law”:
\[(\text{brain}) \propto (\text{body})^\alpha\]
. . .
Check your understanding: what’s the proportionality constant?

title: Lecture 02
text:
Interpretation
So it appears that the brain-body scaling is well-described by a power law:

among selected specimens of these 62 species of mammal, species average brain weight is approximately proportional to a power of species average body weight

. . .
Notice that I did not say:

animals’ brains are proportional to a power of their bodies
among these 62 mammals, average brain weight is approximately proportional to a power of average body weight

title: Lecture 02
text:
Question refinement
We can now ask further, more specific questions:

Do other types of animals exhibit the same power law relationship?

. . .
To investigate, we need richer data.

title: Lecture 02
text:
(More) data acquisition
A number of authors have compiled and published ‘meta-analysis’ datasets by combining the results of multiple studies.
Below we’ll import a few of these for three different animal classes.

# import metaanalysis datasets
reptiles = pd.read_csv('../data/reptile_meta.csv')
birds = pd.read_csv('../data/bird_meta.csv', encoding = 'latin1')
mammals = pd.read_csv('../data/mammal_meta.csv', encoding = 'latin1')

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data assessment
Where does this data come from? It’s kind of a convenience sample of scientific data:

Multiple studies \(\rightarrow\) possibly different sampling and measurement protocols
Criteria for inclusion unknown \(\rightarrow\) probably neither comprehensive nor representative of all such measurements taken

. . .
So these data, while richer, are still relatively narrow in terms of generalizability.

# variables of interest
rept_vars = reptiles.columns[[0, 1, 2, 3, 7, 9, 11]].tolist()
bird_vars = birds.columns[[0, 1, 2, 3, 6, 11, 10]].tolist()
mammal_vars = mammals.columns[[0, 1, 2, 3, 6, 14, 11]].tolist()

# rename columns to consistent names
rept = reptiles.loc[:, rept_vars].rename(columns = {'Body weight (g)': 'body',
                                             'Brain weight (g)': 'brain'})

bird = birds.loc[:, bird_vars].rename(columns = {'Body mass (g)': 'body',
                                           'Brain mass (g)': 'brain'})

mamm = mammals.loc[:, mammal_vars].rename(columns = {'Body mass (g)': 'body',
                                           'Brain mass (g)': 'brain'})

# add animal indicator
mamm['class'] = 'Mammal'
bird['class'] = 'Bird'
rept['class'] = 'Reptile'

# concatenate
frames = [rept, mamm, bird]
data = pd.concat(frames)

title: Lecture 02
section: A comment on scope of inference
text:
A comment on scope of inference
These data don’t support general inferences (e.g., to all animals, all mammals, etc.) because they weren’t collected for the purpose to which we’re putting them.
. . .
Usually, if data are not collected for the explicit purpose of the question you’re trying to answer, they won’t constitute a representative sample.

title: Lecture 02
Lecture 02
text:
Inspection
This dataset has quite a lot of missing brain weight measurements: many of the studies combined to form these datasets did not include that particular measurement.

# missing values?
data.isna().mean(axis = 0)

Order      0.00000
Family     0.00000
Genus      0.00000
Species    0.00000
Sex        0.00000
body       0.00000
brain      0.57404
class      0.00000
dtype: float64



# aggregate by species
avg_weights = data.dropna().groupby(['class', 'Order', 'Species', 'Sex']).mean('body').reset_index()
avg_weights['log(body)'] = np.log(avg_weights['body'])
avg_weights['log(brain)'] = np.log(avg_weights['brain'])

title: Lecture 02
text:
Exploration
Focusing on the nonmissing values, we see the same power law relationship but with different proportionality constants and exponents for the three classes of animals.

scatter = alt.Chart(
  avg_weights
).mark_circle(
  size = 60,
  opacity = 0.2
).encode(
    x = 'log(body)',
    y = 'log(brain)',
    color = 'class'
)

trend = scatter.transform_regression(
  'log(body)', 
  'log(brain)', 
  groupby = ['class']
).mark_line(
  size = 4
)


alt.layer(
  scatter, trend
).configure(
  background='#002b36',
).configure_axis(
  labelFontSize=20,
  titleFontSize=30,
  labelColor = 'white',
  titleColor = 'white'
).configure_legend(
  titleColor = 'white',
  labelColor = 'white',
  titleFontSize = 25,
  labelFontSize = 20,
  symbolOpacity = 1
)

title: Lecture 02
text:
Analysis
So we might hypothesize that:
\[
\begin{align*}
(\text{brain}) & = \beta_1(\text{body})^{\alpha_1} & \text{(mammal)} \\
(\text{brain}) & = \beta_2(\text{body})^{\alpha_2} & \text{(reptile)} \\
(\text{brain}) & = \beta_3(\text{body})^{\alpha_3} & \text{(bird)} \\
\beta_i \neq \beta_j, & \quad  \alpha_i \neq \alpha_j  & \text{for } i \neq j
\end{align*}
\]

title: Lecture 02
text:
Interpretation
It seems that the average brain and body weights of the birds, mammals, and reptiles measured in these studies exhibit distinct power law relationships.
. . .
What would you investigate next?

Correlates of body weight?
Adjust for lifespan, habitat, predation, etc.?
Estimate the \(\alpha_i\)’s and \(\beta_i\)’s?
Predict brain weights for unobserved species?
Something else?

title: Lecture 02
text:
A comment
Notice that I did not mention the word ‘model’ anywhere!
. . .
This was intentional – it is a common misconception that analyzing data always involves fitting models.

Models are not not always necessary or appropriate
You can learn a lot from exploratory techniques
Models approximate specific kinds of relationships in data
Exploratory analysis can reveal unexpected structure

title: Lecture 02
section: But if we did want to fit a model…
text:
But if we did want to fit a model…
\((\text{brain}) = \beta_j(\text{body})^{\alpha_j} \quad \text{animal class } j = 1, 2, 3\)

import matplotlib as mpl
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import statsmodels.api as sm
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf

data = avg_weights.loc[:, ['class', 'brain', 'body']].rename(columns={'class':'animal_type'})

body_rep = pd.concat([avg_weights.body, avg_weights.body, avg_weights.body], axis = 1)

x1 = pd.get_dummies(avg_weights.iloc[:, 0])
x2 = x1 * np.log(body_rep).values
x2 = x2.rename(columns={'Bird': 'log.body.bird', 'Mammal': 'log.body.mammal', 'Reptile': 'log.body.reptile'})

x = pd.concat([x1, x2], axis = 1)
y = np.log(avg_weights.brain)

fit = sm.OLS(y, x.astype(float)).fit()


print(np.asarray(x))

title: Lecture 02
section: But if we did want to fit a model…
text:
But if we did want to fit a model…

FigureEstimates



x = np.linspace(0, 100000, 100)  
y1 = np.exp(fit.params[0])*(x**fit.params[3])
y2 = np.exp(fit.params[1])*(x**fit.params[4])
y3 = np.exp(fit.params[2])*(x**fit.params[5])

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6, 3.5), layout='constrained')
ax.plot(x/1000, y1, label='birds')  # Plot some data on the axes.
ax.plot(x/1000, y2, label='mammals')  # Plot more data on the axes...

ax.set_xlabel('body weight (kg)',
  fontsize = 18,
  color = 'white')  # Add an x-label to the axes.
ax.set_ylabel('median brain weight (g)',
  fontsize = 18,
  color = 'white')  # Add a y-label to the axes.
ax.legend()  # Add a legend.

ax.set_facecolor('#002b36')
fig.set_facecolor('#002b36')
ax.tick_params(colors='white')

plt.show()

title: Lecture 02
text:
Model limitations
Back to the issue of representativeness:

shouldn’t use this model for inferences
might not be reliable for prediction either
but does capture/convey some suggestive comparisons

. . .
So, just be careful with interpretation of results:

“For this particular collection of specimens, we estimated…”

title: Lecture 02
text:
Zooming out
This example illustrates the aspects of the lifecylce we’ll cover in this class:

data retrieval and import
tidying and transformation
visualization
exploratory analysis
modeling

. . .
We’ll address these topics in sequence.

title: Lecture 02

title: Lecture 02
Lecture 02
text:
What Is Data Science?

Still some debate; there isn’t one single agreed-upon definition.
Most people agree Data Science is Cross-Disciplinary; i.e. it lies at the intersection of many fields.
Often, data scientists are concerned with contributing knowledge by way of combining three things: statistical theory and methodology, with computer science technology, and domain-specific knowledge.

For example, to make claims about air quality, a data scientist might utilize appropriate statistical methodology in conjunction with sophisticated computer science algorithms, along with specific knowledge from ecology, atmospheric science, anthropology, and potentially many other fields.

title: Lecture 02
text:
Collaborative!

As such, data science is inherently collaborative!

As a Data Scientist, you will very often be working with experts from a variety of different fields (sometimes all at once).
This is true both from an academic standpoint (i.e. if you plan to pursue a data science career in academia) and from an industry standpoint.

This is part of the reason the projects in PSTAT 100 are completed in groups: to give you practice with project management in a group setting.

title: Lecture 02
text: Data Science Lifecycle

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data Science Lifecycle






Two possible entry points: with a question or with a data set



Are you starting your analyses with a specific question in mind? (“How has air quality changed over time?” “What factors affect feline contraction of FIV?” etc.)




Or, are you starting with a specific dataset you want to explore, from which you will (ultimately) formulate a question of interest?

title: Lecture 02
text:
Data Science Lifecycle






The exact steps are not that important (and also not fully agreed-upon).



The main idea is of an iterative process.




Maybe your data will change the question you ask. Maybe, after a first pass, you will realize you need additional data.

title: PSTAT 100: Data Science Concepts and Analysis
text:

title: Lecture 05
text:
Leadup

We’ve done a fair bit of work discussing data.
One question we haven’t really addressed, is: where does data come from?
Firstly, why should we care about this?
Remember: a crucial part of being a good data scientist is understanding our data as best we can.
Part of this understanding entails understanding the mechanisms by which the data was collected, as these mechanisms can sometimes shed light on aspects of the data that were previously unseen.

title: Lecture 05
text:
Sampling

There are three main things to keep in mind when it comes to sampling (which is typically the manner in which data is collected): the Target Population, the Access Frame, and the Sample.
The target population refers to the set of observational units (remember these? these could be people, animals, countries, etc.) that we would like to investigate/make claims about.
The access frame refers to the set of elements that we can actually reach/observe. In an ideal situation this would be the same as the target population, but in practice there may be differences (as we’ll see in a bit).
Finally, the sample is the subset of elements taken from the access frame that we actually end up observing.

title: Lecture 05
text:
Example: Telephone Surveys

To make things explicit, let’s consider an example of telephone surveys.



An election is coming up, and the campaign manager of Candidate X has hired us to determine which US voters are most likely to vote for Candidate X.





UCSB: Department of Statistics and Applied Probability

title: Lecture 05
text:
Example: Voting Telephone Surveys

To make things explicit, let’s consider an example of telephone surveys.



An election is coming up, and the campaign manager of Candidate X has hired us to determine which US voters are most likely to vote for Candidate X.



Here, the target population would be the set of all US voters.




UCSB: Department of Statistics and Applied Probability

title: Lecture 05
text:
Example: Voting

To make things explicit, let’s consider an example of telephone surveys.



An election is coming up, and the campaign manager of Candidate X has hired us to determine (by way of telephone surveys) which US voters are most likely to vote for Candidate X.



Here, the target population would be the set of all US voters.
The access frame, however, will not be the same as the target population.

title: Lecture 05
text:
Example: Voting

Why? Well, for one thing- not all US voters have a phone.
Additionally, the access frame simply includes all people reachable by phone, which will include people outside the target population (e.g. teenagers under the age of 18, non-US-citizens, convicted felons, all of whom are ineligible to vote by US law).
So, the relationship between the target population and the access frame might be visualized as something like this:

title: Lecture 05
text: Example: Voting

title: Lecture 05
text:
Example: Voting

Finally, our sample will be drawn from the sampled population (i.e. the intersection between the access frame and the target population).
We’ll spend a considerable portion of today’s lecture talking about this step; for now, let’s try and example in pairs/small groups.

title: Lecture 05
text:
Your Turn!






Your Turn!



“Beginner’s Luck” refers to the (supposed) phenomenon by which first-time participants in a game or sport seem to perform abnormally well.
Suppose a recent study claimed that “15% of first-time poker players earned above-average net winnings across their first 10 games played.” The study later clarified that the data was collected by surveying 100 randomly-selected poker players at 5 different LA-area casinos.
Identify (in words) the target population and access frame. Provide examples of individuals who are in the access frame but not the target population, and vice-versa.

title: Lecture 05
text:
Sampling

Alright, so hopefully we’re now convinced that sampling is a good idea.
How do we do it?




UCSB: Department of Statistics and Applied Probability

title: Lecture 05
text:
Why Sample?

We’ll now devote some time to talking about sampling procedures.
Firstly, a question we should answer is: why bother taking samples at all?
Well, firstly, a census (in which every observations are made on every single observational unit in the target population) is almost always practically impossible.

This is usually due to the high costs (in time, money, effort, etc.) associated with a census.

Even if we were able to take a census (which is sometimes possible), there is no guarantee this data would be perfect- it could have been sloppily recorded, it could have errors, etc.

title: Lecture 05
text:
Why Sample?

There are also some situations in which observational units must be destroyed in order to be observed.

Lighthearted example: chocolate chips in cookies.
Less lighthearted example: post-mortem studies

In such cases, taking a census would eliminate the population entirely, making resampling impossible. (Not to mention- it’s just rude!)

title: Lecture 05
text:
How To Sample?

Alright, so hopefully we’re now convinced that sampling is a good idea.
How do we do it?
There are many sampling schemes (aka sampling methods) available. Four common ones are:

Simple Random Sampling
Stratified Sampling
Cluster Sampling
Convenience Sampling

title: Lecture 05
text:
Some Notation

Let’s start off by introducing some mathematical notation. Let \(U_i\) denote an observational unit, and:


\[\begin{align*}
  \mathcal{U}   & := \{U_i\}_{i \in I}    & \text{(universe)}   \\
    T_P          &= \{U_1, \dots, U_N\} \subseteq \mathcal{U} & \text{(target pop.)} \\
    F           &= \{U_j: j \in J \subset I\} & \text{(frame)} \\
    S_P           &:= T_P \cap F & \text{(sampled pop.)}   \\
    S           &\subseteq S_P &    \text{(sample)}
\end{align*}\]


I: set of indices corresponding to the universe
N: total number of observational units in the target population
J: set of indices corresponding to observational units in the frame

title: Lecture 05
text: Notation

title: Lecture 05
text:
Simple Random Sampling

In a Simple Random Sample, we simply take a subset of size \(n\) from the access frame.
A hallmark of simple random sampling is that every observational unit has an equal chance of being included in the sample, independently of other observational units.

We’ll talk more about the probabilistic mechanisms underpinning sampling in a bit; right now, I’m just trying to give a high-level overview of some of the different sampling schemes.

title: Lecture 05
text:
Stratified Sampling



In a Stratified Sample (sometimes called a Stratified Random Sample), we first divide the access frame into several strata (groups), and then take an SRS from each stratum.








Note that, by construction, each stratum will be represented in the sample.

title: Lecture 05
text:
Cluster Sampling



In a Cluster Sample, we also begin by dividing the access frame into groups (now called clusters).
However, instead of taking an SRS from each cluster, we first take an SRS of clusters, and then take an SRS from each of the included clusters.








This means, in cluster sampling, some clusters will not be represented in the final sample.

title: Lecture 05
text:
Convenience Sampling

A convenience sample, much like the name suggests, refers to a sample that is taken purely out of convenience.

For instance, surveying the first 10 people you see on the street.

Convenience sampling is (out of the sampling methods) most prone to different forms of bias (which we’ll talk about in a bit), but can be a quick and easy way to obtain data.

title: Lecture 05
text: Comparison

title: Mini-Project 1
text:
Welcome to the first PSTAT 100 Mini-Project! Please keep in mind that mini-projects will be (intentionally) a bit open-ended. This is because most “real-world” data science projects - whether they be in industry or in academia - are also open-ended. Instead of having a set series of questions that can be answered with only one or two methods, project-type questions can often be answered in many different ways, using many different techniques.
We do expect your final product to be more akin to a report than a homework set, though we will not necessarily expect all of the formality of an academic paper (we’re saving that for the final project). Having said that, here are some things to keep in mind:

title: Mini-Project 1
text:
Introduction
Many governmental agencies report free-to-use data on their website. This also includes city-level administration. In this project, we will be consulting a series of datasets that were uploaded by the City of Seattle, in this database. Our particular goal in this project is to study the trees maintained by the City of Seattle. We will do so by way of a series of statistical graphics; reports of this type (that seek to explore data and answer questions through plots) are sometimes called visualization reports.

Background
One of the goals of this project is to give you practice with generating geographic maps in R. In the cartographic1 world, objects are typically identified by a pair of points called a coordinate. Geographical coordinates consist of a latitude and longitude value, which can be thought of like x- and y-coordinates in a Cartesian coordinate system, respectively.





Depiction of Latitude and Longitude; source: https://cdn.britannica.com/07/64907-050-7ACA69C8/Facts-parallels-Lines-of-Latitude-angles-direction.jpg




Data Description
For this project, we will primarily be working with two files. The first file is called SDOT_Trees.csv, which contains the bulk of the data we are analyzing. A data dictionary can be found here2
The second file is called borders.shp, and contains information about the city and neighborhood geographic boundaries (stored in what is known as a shape file; you don’t need to know what this means for this project).

title: Mini-Project 1
text:
Data
The particular datasets can be found in the data subfolder the MP01 directory (accessible on the course server), and are titled trees.csv and borders.csv. The trees.csv file contains observations on the following variables:

LIST

and the borders.csv file is used for storing geographical information about city and neighborhood limits.
